title: Greg Tonoski
author: Greg Tonoski
content: Can I ask you for the information about %of transaction that are accelerated, please? I'm trying to find whether it increases month-by-month, at what rate and how many tx out of the total (in a block) are accelerated. Approximate values would do. Thanks in advance.

comments.author: adaseb
comments.body: This is probably very hard to calculate.Reason being is that a low fee transaction usually is bumped off the mempool. Or it’s never even broadcasted with most nodes.Then if the sender uses RBF then it appears like a new transaction. Only certain nodes can tell that it was accelerated with a higher fee because they see 2 transactions which might trigger a double spend.

comments.author: Greg Tonoski
comments.body: Quote from: adaseb on March 10, 2024, 05:22:45 AMThis is probably very hard to calculate.Reason being is that a low fee transaction usually is bumped off the mempool. Or it’s never even broadcasted with most nodes.Agree that it may be hard to calculate. Not impossible, though. There are 0 fee txs included in blocks - apparently out-of-band. Also there are accelerator services that report their activity, e.g. "https://mempool.space/acceleration".

comments.author: PrivacyG
comments.body: Quote from: Greg Tonoski on March 10, 2024, 12:15:57 PMAgree that it may be hard to calculate. Not impossible, though. There are 0 fee txs included in blocks - apparently out-of-band. Also there are accelerator services that report their activity, e.g. "https://mempool.space/acceleration". Since the Miner is the one who includes these Transactions in a Block.  The only variable is how many Transactions they decide to accelerate per Block now versus how many they used to.But then, other than zero Fee Transactions that are included in the Block, I do not see how we could check and create some sort of chart or percentage, even if approximated, on how many Transactions are accelerated.  This would be too speculative and unless the speculated percentages are very tight, I believe the chance of properly checking how many are accelerated now versus years ago is close to null.
